title.narrative: Community management of acute malnutrition in Huila province

description.narrative: To reduce mortality and morbidity attributable to malnutrition, WFP will support the Ministry of Health In response to the crisis in providing lifesaving services for the community-based management of acute malnutrition. WFP and partners will organize short refresher sessions for community health agents who will perform nutrition screening and treatment at the community level. Uncomplicated cases of Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) will be treated at the community level. In contrast, cases with complications and Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) cases will be referred to a health facility. To enhance the prevention of malnutrition, WFP will work closely with the health services, partners, Community Based Organizations (CBO), and parents to promote social behavior change communication, mass and community media activities to reach families and caregivers. In total, 128,351 persons will benefit, including 5,195 women, 58,117 boys and 64,939 girls. UNFPA also expects to reach 3,208 people with disabilities.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to CERF Project Community management of acute malnutrition in Huila province

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: 123,056 CU5 are screened in 5 municipalities in the drought-affected province of Huila and at least 13,397 children with Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) receive treatment at the community level (targeted supplementary feeding programme)

CC.1 Number of frontline aid workers (e.g. partner personnel) who received short refresher training to support programme implementation(refresher sessions in screening and treatment of moderate acute malnutrition at the community level)
FN.1b Quantity of food assistance distributed in MT ( ready-to-use supplementary food)

N.2a Number of moderately acutely malnourished people enrolled in supplementary feeding programme (children under five; cases with complications will be referred to a relevant health unit, and cases at the community level will be followed up by the corresponding agents)
N.4 Number of people screened for acute malnutrition (children under five, disaggregated by sex, in the 5 municipalities of Huila province)

29,996 family members receive counselling on early detection of malnutrition signs and positive IYCF, health and hygiene preventative practices (including sensitization on MUAC screening for 5,095 mothers and caregivers)

N.6 Number of people benefitting training and/or community awareness sessions on infant and young child feeding in emergencies (family members and caregivers of children 0-59 months with access to counselling on early detection of malnutrition signs and positive IYCF, health and hygiene preventative practices (at the community level, as compared to UNICEF which will be supporting counselling at the health unit level))
Number of mothers and caregivers benefiting from sensitization sessions on the family MUAC approach
